articles.headline: As Migrant Children Were Put to Work, U.S. Ignored Warnings
articles.snippet: The White House and federal agencies were repeatedly alerted to signs of children at risk. The warnings were ignored or missed.
articles.abstract: The White House and federal agencies were repeatedly alerted to signs of children at risk. The warnings were ignored or missed.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the spring of 2021, Linda Brandmiller was working at an arena in San Antonio that had been converted into an emergency shelter for migrant children. Thousands of boys were sleeping on cots as the Biden administration grappled with a record number of minors crossing into the United States without their parents.

articles.headline: 84-Year-Old Is Charged in Shooting of Black Teenager Who Went to Wrong House
articles.snippet: Lawyers for the family of Ralph Yarl, 16, said he was critically injured when he was shot twice in Kansas City, Mo.
articles.abstract: Lawyers for the family of Ralph Yarl, 16, said he was critically injured when he was shot twice in Kansas City, Mo.
articles.lead_paragraph: The errand that nearly cost Ralph Yarl his life was of the sort that falls to older brothers everywhere.
articles.byline: By Livia Albeck-Ripka, Patrick LaForge and Christine Hauser

articles.headline: Hollywood Writers Approve of Strike as Shutdown Looms
articles.snippet: The writers have not gone on strike in 15 years, and the vote gives their unions the right to call for a walkout when their contract expires on May 1.
articles.abstract: The writers have not gone on strike in 15 years, and the vote gives their unions the right to call for a walkout when their contract expires on May 1.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hollywood is getting ever closer to a shutdown.
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: After American’s Killing in Syria, F.B.I. Builds War Crimes Case Against Top Officials
articles.snippet: The inquiry aims to hold to account Syrian officials considered key architects of a brutal system of detention and torture that has flourished under President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.abstract: The inquiry aims to hold to account Syrian officials considered key architects of a brutal system of detention and torture that has flourished under President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, guards at a Syrian prison brutally tortured an American aid worker and threatened to kill her loved ones. She eventually caved to their demands, confessing to crimes she did not commit. A trial that lasted no more than a few minutes followed, and she was ordered executed in late 2016.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: DeSantis, in Latest Volley Against Disney, Suggests Punitive Steps
articles.snippet: The Florida governor also described proposed legislation he said would override the company’s effort to sidestep oversight of its theme parks.
articles.abstract: The Florida governor also described proposed legislation he said would override the company’s effort to sidestep oversight of its theme parks.
articles.lead_paragraph: In what has taken on the trappings of a grudge match, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida punched Disney anew on Monday, announcing new legislation that would override the company’s recent effort to sidestep state oversight of its theme parks.

articles.headline: Hospitals and Aid Groups Become Targets as Sudan Fighting Intensifies
articles.snippet: Civilians are caught in the cross-fire, and two rival generals vying for power made it clear their forces had no intention of standing down.
articles.abstract: Civilians are caught in the cross-fire, and two rival generals vying for power made it clear their forces had no intention of standing down.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — As two rival generals, each with his own army, grappled for power in Sudan on Monday, even hospitals trying to tend to the swelling numbers of wounded were no longer havens.
articles.byline: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Declan Walsh

articles.headline: With ‘Zero Covid’ Behind It, China’s Economy Starts to Recover
articles.snippet: The economy grew 4.5 percent in the first three months of the year, a sizable pickup from the end of 2022, when the relaxation of pandemic prevention measures led to a wave of illness.
articles.abstract: The economy grew 4.5 percent in the first three months of the year, a sizable pickup from the end of 2022, when the relaxation of pandemic prevention measures led to a wave of illness.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s consumers, while wary of big-ticket purchases like cars or apartments, are spending again. Many factories are still running below capacity, but exports are strengthening. Even as construction of new housing is slowing, investment in infrastructure and manufacturing is robust.

articles.headline: DeSantis Tried to Bury Her. Now She’s Helping Trump Try to Bury Him.
articles.snippet: Susie Wiles helped Ron DeSantis become governor of Florida, but he turned against her and banished her from his orbit. Donald Trump was all too happy to bring her in from the cold.
articles.abstract: Susie Wiles helped Ron DeSantis become governor of Florida, but he turned against her and banished her from his orbit. Donald Trump was all too happy to bring her in from the cold.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two months before Election Day 2020, Susie Wiles stood uncomfortably inside a hospitality tent in Florida, caught between two proud and exacting men whom she had helped elect: President Donald J. Trump and Gov. Ron DeSantis.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer, Maggie Haberman and Michael C. Bender

articles.headline: How Mexico Became the Biggest User of the World’s Most Notorious Spy Tool
articles.snippet: A Times investigation reveals the story behind how Mexico became the first and most prolific user of Pegasus. It’s still using it, despite promising to stop.
articles.abstract: A Times investigation reveals the story behind how Mexico became the first and most prolific user of Pegasus. It’s still using it, despite promising to stop.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Israelis had come to Mexico to clinch a major sale: The Mexican military was about to become the first client ever to buy their product, the world’s most advanced spyware.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: Russian Court Rejects Wall Street Journal Reporter’s Appeal
articles.snippet: It was the first time that Evan Gershkovich, a 31-year-old American, has been seen clearly since he was detained last month and accused of espionage.
articles.abstract: It was the first time that Evan Gershkovich, a 31-year-old American, has been seen clearly since he was detained last month and accused of espionage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Evan Gershkovich, the Wall Street Journal reporter arrested in Russia on suspicion of espionage, declared his innocence in a Moscow courtroom on Tuesday after flashing a smile from a glass defendant’s cage. It was his first public appearance since his detention last month, a new escalation in President Vladimir V. Putin’s conflict with the West.
articles.byline: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Anton Troianovski

articles.headline: Russia Is Importing Western Weapons Technology, Bypassing Sanctions
articles.snippet: Western technology goods are winding up in Russian missiles, raising questions about the efficacy of sanctions.
articles.abstract: Western technology goods are winding up in Russian missiles, raising questions about the efficacy of sanctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late last month, American and European Union officials traded information on millions of dollars’ worth of banned technology that was slipping through the cracks of their defenses and into Russian territory.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

articles.headline: Apple Opens First Store in India, a Promising Frontier for the Tech Giant
articles.snippet: Tim Cook, the chief executive of the iPhone maker, visited Mumbai to inaugurate the store. Apple is pushing to expand its market share in India, as well as shift some production there.
articles.abstract: Tim Cook, the chief executive of the iPhone maker, visited Mumbai to inaugurate the store. Apple is pushing to expand its market share in India, as well as shift some production there.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tim Cook, the chief executive of Apple, visited India this week to open the company’s first two Apple stores there: The biggest public company in the world is finally opening its first retail outlets in the world’s most populous country.
articles.byline: By Alex Travelli and Suhasini Raj
